occurrences.line_text: That the weake soule her seat did yet retaine,
Which vertue it for euer after did retaine.
And taking downe the shield, with me did it retaine.
Who sore against his will did him retaine,
Whose bad condition yet it doth retaine,
Till we may be assur'd they shall their course retaine.
Yet could it not sterne Artegall retaine,
But Calidore himselfe would not retaine
Of Podalyrius did in it retaine,
But th'vpper halfe their hew retained still,
Yet still with gentle countenaunce retained,
Euen thrise eleuen descents the crowne retaynd,
But to her selfe it secretly retayned,
With lighter hearts vnto their home retird;
Then home he suffred her for to retire,
Til breathlesse both them selues aside retire,
To Vna back he cast him to retire;
So sore him noyd, that forst him to retire
That were it not for shame, he would retire,
For life ere long shall to her home retire,
With foule repulse from Fraunce was forced to retire.
And backe retire, all scorcht and pitifully brent.
Backe to retire, and somewhat to relent,
He bad him stay, and backe with him retire;
And otherwise, if that he should retire,
The other backe retired, and contrarie trode.
The way they came, the same retourn'd they right,
Vnto her natiue prison to retourne:
To tast of ioy, and to wont pleasures to retourne.
At length, when as no hope of his retourne
Which done, vnto his former iourney he retourned.
Whose faire retrait I in my shield do beare;
So sounded the retraite, and drew his folke away.
To stay the steppe, ere forced to retrate.
But him the Squire made quickly to retrate,
Working belgards, and amorous retrate,
As fast as forward erst, now backward to retrate.
That shortly them compelled to retrate,
In entrance, did me also friend in my retrate.
To be conuayed in, ere she would once retrate.
But yet so fast they could not home retrate,
That whether quite from them for to retrate
That she him forced backward to retreat,
And forst him backe with fowle dishonor to retreat.
But his wast wordes returnd to him in vaine:
With that misformed spright he backe returnd againe.
Returnd to stately pallace of dame Pride;
To haue returnd, but dazed were his eyne,
She to her vse returnd, and streight defyde
A while they fled, but soone returnd againe
Thrise she her turnd contrary, and returnd,
Ne euer to his worke returnd againe:
So with the Dwarfe he backe return'd againe,
That hast from darkenesse me returnd to light,
And was return'd againe vnto his Dame,
Once hauing turnd, no more returnd his face,
Like as Minerua, being late returnd
His weary eie returnd to him againe,
But when he to himselfe returnd againe,
And wish to life return'd againe to bee,
Return'd to heauen, whence she deriu'd her race;
She vnto Talus forth return'd againe,
Sir Artegall return'd from his late quest,
He wearie woxe, and backe return'd againe
Himselfe recouering, was return'd to fight;
When weening to returne, whence they did stray,
To wish you backe returne with foule disgrace,
Returne from whence ye came, and rest a while
They gan to fight returne, increasing more
And shortly backe returne vnto this place,
Backe to returne to that great Faerie Queene,
Ye then shall hither backe returne againe,
Vnto his Farie Queene backe to returne:
May backe returne, but is condemned to be drent.
Ne did the other backe his foot returne,
Them bound till his returne, their labour not to slake.
And vowed neuer to returne againe,
Till they againe returne backe by the hinder gate.
Till thither they returne, where first they grew:
Till we returne againe in safetie:
And home returne, where all should be renewd
Awayted there for Britomarts returne,
Backe to him selfe he gan returne the blame,
Ne former strength returne so suddenly,
And safe returne, he was full inly glad,
For his returne, she waited had for nought,
But when as yet she saw him not returne,
Ne none can backe returne, that once are gone amis.
And to your selfe doe it returne againe:
Till his returne vnto this tree he bond:
To whom that other did this taunt returne.
He with him thought backe to returne againe:
That he dare not returne for all his daily vaunt.
All is in time like to returne againe
Mote him auaile, but to returne againe
Therefore resoluing to returne in hast
She backe returned with some labour lost;
But few returned, hauing scaped hard,
They backe returned to the Princely Place;
That backe returned without heauenly grace;
Both fled attonce, ne euer backe returned eie.
And then againe returned to their restes:
His wanton sports, being returned late
The king returned proud of victorie,
Let them returned be vnto their former state.
Returned home, the royall Infant fell
After that they againe returned beene,
With that same Squyre, returned backe againe
She turned her, and returned backe againe:
And then returned, hauing marched thrise,
Returned readie newes, that those same weare
And backe returned with right heauie mind,
Being returned to his mothers bowre,
Being returned to his former hew:
Tho as he backe returned from that land,
Which I no lesse disdayning, backe returned
That soone as he returned backe againe,
He backe returned to his rusticke wonne,
Who when he backe returned from the wood,
He backe returning by the Yuorie dore,
Returning to his bed in torment great,
And backe returning tooke her wonted way,
Who when returning from the drery Night,
From whom returning sad and comfortlesse,
I home returning, fraught with fowle despight,
Into the which returning backe, he fell:
Eft fierce returning, as a Faulcon faire
So braue returning, with his brandisht blade,
He liu'd, returning to his natiue place,
Thence backe returning to the former land,
Late forth she sent, she backe returning spyde,
Returning backe, those goodly roomes, which erst
Who backe returning, told as he had seene,
Returning, disappointed his desire,
Then backe returning, where his Dame did lie,
Yet being forst to abide the daies returning,
With Artegall, returning yet halfe sad
So all returning to the Castle glad,
Which answer when the groome returning, brought
Tho backe returning to that sorie Dame,
From them returning to that Ladie backe,
Tho backe returning to my sheepe againe,
Then backe returning to his dearest deare,
And back retyrd, his life bloud forth with all did draw.
Backe to the strond retyrd, and there still stayd,
Retyrd their steeds, to ronne in euen race:
Him answered, that all were now retyrd
And though he still retyr'd, yet nathelesse
Came hurtling in full fierce, and forst the knight retyre.
Yet being entred, might not backe retyre;
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
Consum'd, but did him selfe to safetie retyre.
Of her fierce wrath, and backward still retyre,
That forst at first those knights backe to retyre:
But turn'd abacke, and to retyre him hasted
Be but vaine shadowes to this safe retyre
Were turnd, and they to freedome did retyre.
And would haue backe retyred to her caue,
Which doen, he backe retyred soft away,
Backe to that desert forrest they retyred,
He would haue backe retyred from that sight,
Proceeded, lo now is reueald to thee.
Were vnto him reueald in vision,
Of the Riphoean hils, to her reueald
His ioyous face did to the world reueale,
And bad, that none their ioyous treason should reueale.
And passing beautie did eftsoones reueale,
My selfe, till that the Dwarfe did me reueale,
It to reueale: who still her answered, there was nought.
The skill whereof to Princes hearts he doth reueale.
And that same yron man which could reueale
I would thy selfe require thee to reueale,
To her reuealed in a mirrhour plaine,
Yet neuer he his hart to her reuealed,
Iwill reuele, what ye so much desire:
And th'amarous sweet spoiles to greedy eyes reuele.
The which the powres to thee are pleased to reuele.
And rare in-sight, hard matters to reuele;
Reuele to me the sacred noursery
Dauncing and reueling both day and night,
Had fild, that he to fell reueng was fully bent.
Cruell reuenge, which he in hart did hyde,
Leaue roaring, when in rage he for reuenge did earne.
So long they fight, and fell reuenge pursue,
His neighbour element in his reuenge:
That short reuenge the man may ouertake,
The doome of iust reuenge, and take delight
Of his reuenge to make the instrument:
And grimly gnash, threatning reuenge in vaine:
Kindles Reuenge, and threats his rusty knife;
Of whom sore hurt, for his reuenge
Nor care of vow'd reuenge, and cruell fight,
The hastie heat of his auowd reuenge delayd.
Cruell Reuenge, and rancorous Despight,
Of vile reuenge. To spoile the dead of weed
Making aduantage, to reuenge their spight,
His life for due reuenge should deare abie?
And with reuenge desiring soone to dye,
But casting wrongs and all reuenge behind,
For to reuenge that foule reprochfull shame,
From rash reuenge, she had him surely slaine,
To reskew her from shame, and to reuenge her wrong.
Are bound for to reuenge, and punish if they may.
For life she him enuyde, and long'd reuenge to see.
Ne list I for reuenge prouoke new fight,
He for reuenge had guiltlesse Glauce slaine:
That from reuenge their willes they scarse asswag'd:
Bent to reuenge on blamelesse Britomart
That nought but dire reuenge his anger mote defray.
Of fell reuenge, in their malicious mood
Therefore resoluing to reuenge his blood,
Them to disable from reuenge aduenturing.
She mote reuenge that blot, which on her lay.
How to reuenge that blot of honour blent;
Those warlike weedes, till she reuenge had wrought
But in reuenge both of her loues distresse,
But all in his reuenge of spirite would depriue.
Of more reuenge? if more, then I am shee,
Which was the roote of all, end your reuenge on mee.
All flaming with reuenge and furious despight.
That him to no reuenge he forth could call,
Ne secretly from thought of fell reuenge surceasse.
Did worthily reuenge this maydens pride;
Or if it to reuenge he were too weake,
To haue reuenged that his villeny;
From his reuengefull purpose shronke abacke,
Where though reuengefull vow she did professe,
In cancred malice and reuengefull spright.
In her sonnes flesh, to minde reuengement,
And in reuengement of his owne despight,
And for reuengement of those wrongfull smarts,
The rash reuengers heat. Words well dispost
Halfe mad through malice, and reuenging will,
And him beside rides fierce reuenging VVrath,
I wote not, whether the reuenging steele
What direfull chance, armd with reuenging fate,
Then fowle reuenging rage, and base contentious iarre.
The greedy hunger of reuenging ire,
From prosecuting his reuenging rage;
From dread of her reuenging fathers hond:
With the reuenue of her plenteous meedes:
Hight Reuerence. He them with speeches meet
And alwayes led, to her with reuerence rare
Whom highly he did reuerence and adore,
She to her Sire made humble reuerence,
Religious reuerence doth buriall teene,
Do her adore with sacred reuerence,
And to the Prince bowing with reuerence dew,
The knights there entring, did him reuerence dew
And sacred Reuerence, yborne of heauenly strene,
His reuerend haires and holy grauitie
Behold this heauie sight, thou reuerend Sire,
Said he then to the Palmer, Reuerend syre,
And to his fresh remembrance did reuerse
Out of her daughters hart fond fancies to reuerse.
Or doen they onely sleepe, and shall againe reuerse?
Those cursed leaues, his charmes backe to reuerse;
As in reuersion of his brothers right;
That by no reason it might be reuerst,
He vnto her would speedily reuert:
Did thus reuest, and deckt with due habiliments.
But when his meane estate he did reuew,
All that she might, and him in vaine reuild:
And him reuil'd, and rated, and disdayned,
And me in lieu thereof reuil'd againe,
But both himselfe reuil'd, and eke his loue;
To be vniustly blamd, and bitterly reuilde.
Streight gan he him reuile, and bitter rate,
And Florimell him fowly gan reuile,
Then th'other comming neare, gan him reuile,
And to reuile, and rate, and recreant call,
See how they doe that Squire beat and reuile;
The whiles the foole did him reuile and flout,
And sharpely at him to reuile and raile,
Them follow'd fast, and them reuiled sore,
And him reuiled, and reproched sore
Her bitter rayling and foule reuilement,
Reuiling me, and rayling as she lust,
Him still reuiling and afflicting sore,
His chearefull words reuiu'd her chearelesse spright,
She was reuiu'd, and ioyd much in his semblance glad.
Of natiue vertue gan eftsoones reuiue,
When Ioue auizd, that could the dead reuiue,
By vew of her he ginneth to reuiue
Espide, he gan reuiue the memory
This thy demaund, ï¿½ Lady, doth reuiue
Hable to heale the sicke, and to reuiue the ded.
Might not reuiue desire of knightly exercize.
And dying daily, daily yet reuiue:
Which shall reuiue the sleeping memorie
To wreake the wrath, which he did earst reuiue
That I thy labours lost may thus reuiue,
So her vneath at last he did reuiue,
Like to a ghost, that lately is reuiued
His former griefe with furie fresh reuiued,
It would haue liued, and reuiued eft;
Sad death, reuiued with her sweet inspection
Reuiued was, and sad dispaire away did cast.
She sudden was reuiued therewithall,
She it reuiues and new occasion reaches:
Reuiuing thought of glorie and of fame,
Ah Ladie (said he) shame were to reuoke
Still stroue their stubborne rages to reuoke,
Cymochles twise, that twise him forst his foot reuoke.
Enforced them their forward footing to reuoke.
And Talus to reuoke from the right way,
That the faint sprite he did reuoke againe,
Vntill with loue reuokt from vaine affright,
So to her yold the flames, and did their force reuolt,
And the iust reuolution measured,
Ne wonder; for the heauens reuolution
Halfe dead through feare, her litle babe reuyld,
And with big thundring voyce reuyld him lowd;
With which his mother Venus her reuyld,
For that therewith he falsely did reuyle,
And thrise he her reviu'd with busie paine:
Wherewith reviu'd, this answere forth he threw;
Die is my dew: yet rew my wretched state
He would not shend, but said, Deare dame I rew,
And said, Faire Lady hart of flint would rew
That euer to haue toucht her, I did deadly rew.
And said, Deare daughter rightly may I rew
To dare the thing, which daily yet I rew,
Gan her admire, and her sad sorrowes rew,
Aye me, Deare dame (quoth he) well may I rew
This fatall day, that shall I euer rew,
Th'enchaunter vaine his errour should not rew:
Could make a stony hart his hap to rew;
As miserable louers vse to rew,
But vaine: for ye shall dearely do him rew,
Which Mordant and Amauia did rew;
Who shall him rew, that swimming in the maine,
How euer, sure I rew his pitteous plight.
Whose dolefull moniments who list to rew,
Had gathered Rew, and Sauine, and the flowre
But the third time shall rew his foolhardise:
That could haue made a rocke of stone to rew,
Sitting beside a fountaine in a rew,
Set by it selfe, and ranckt in comely rew:
These eyes did see, that they will euer rew
Whom when the Prince beheld, he gan to rew
He cald to him aloud, his case to rew,
That her deare hart full deepely made to rew,
And learne to loue, by learning louers paines to rew.
With a fayre loue, whose losse I now do rew,
That Artegall him selfe her seemelesse plight did rew.
Spinning and carding all in comely rew,
I rew that thus thy better dayes are drowned
Oft did she blame her selfe, and often rew,
And thrown his shield atween, she had him done to rew.
His mightie hart their mournefull case can rew,
That euen his ruder hart began to rew,
Complayning out on me, that would not on them rew.
Where none is nigh to heare, that will her rew,
That who so heares her heauinesse, would rew
Did cast to ground, whilest none was them to rew;
And shall you well reward to shew the place,
Wherewith you to reward? Accept therefore
And to that Damzell thankes gaue for reward.
By riches and vnrighteous reward,
And all for loue, and nothing for reward:
But what reward had he, that ouercame?
(Said they) and haue our Ladies loue for his reward.
To enter in, and reape the dew reward:
Without respect of richesse or reward.
And worthy worke of infinite reward,
Yet not escaped from the dew reward
Sith I her dew reward cannot restore:
Then to reward my trusty true intent,
And eke reward the wretch for his mesprise,
Your worthy paine shall well reward with guerdon rich.
I loath as doung, ne deeme my dew reward:
If good find grace, and righteousnesse reward,
To giue him the reward for such vile outrage dew.
Your vertue selfe her owne reward shall breed,
Said, Gentle Dame, reward enough I weene
Shall haue that golden girdle for reward,
To serue, for want of other meete reward,
And on those Priests bestowed rich reward:
That is the vertue selfe, which her reward doth pay.
I had, you to reward with greater dignitie.
My due reward, the which right well I deeme
You well reward, and golden guerdon giue,
For slaues to sell them, for no small reward,
for ill rewards him well.
Wherewith she sighed soft, as if his case she rewd.
When his foote slipt (that slip he dearely rewd,)
Lay in the lap of death, rewing his wretched bale.
The ruin'd wals he did reï¿½ fÂ¦difye
Swift Rhene, and Alpheus still immaculate:
Of the faire Nimph Rheusa wandring there.
Long Rhodanus, whose sourse springs from the skie;
Of Rhodope, on which the Nimphe, that bore
For Rhodoricke, whose surname shalbe Great,
Like a wood God, and flowing fast to Rhy:
The same he tooke, and with a riband new,
When that lewd ribauld with vile lust aduaunst
The golden ribband, which that virgin wore
Had knowne right well with colourd ribbands drest:
Was hangd on high with golden ribbands laced;
Trayled with ribbands diuersly distraught
Of sundry flowres, with silken ribbands tyde,
And ragged ribs of mountaines molten new,
On whose sharpe clifts the ribs of vessels broke,
Their wooden ribs are shaken nigh a sonder;
Her shattered ribs in thousand peeces riues,
That all his ribs he quite in peeces broke,
And makes her ribs to cracke, as they were torne,
Purfled with gold and pearle of rich assay,
Fight for the rule of the rich fleeced flocke,
Of a most mighty king, most rich and sage;
The holy Saints of their rich vestiments
With rich array and costly arras dight:
And a rich throne, as bright as sunny day,
And stroue to match, in royall rich array,
And win rich spoile of ransackt chastetee.
There all within full rich arayd he found,
Was writ with golden letters rich and braue;
In which were not rich tyres, nor garments gay,
Who rich arayd, and yet in modest guize,
In a rich Iewell, and therein entrayld
And with him brought Priene, rich arayd,
And deck the world with their rich pompous showes;
A worke of rich entayle, and curious mould,
And these rich heapes of wealth doest hide apart
And with rich metall loaded euery rift,
To which all men do ayme, rich to be made:
And his broad braunches, laden with rich fee,
And with rich spoiles and famous victorie,
And the rich wares to saue from pitteous spoyle,
That the weake bowes, with so rich load opprest,
For the rich mettall was so coloured,
And rich purueyance might vneath be red;
A goodly Armour, and full rich aray,
Is throwne on the Rich strond:
She saw bestrowed all with rich aray
Rich strond to trauell, whereas he did wonne,
T'endow her sonne with threasure and rich store,
Of the Rich strond, their charets they forlore,
Her faire lockes in rich circlet be enrold,
And the rich furrowes flote, all quite fordonne:
Of her rich spoyles, whom he had earst destroyd,
Your worthy paine shall well reward with guerdon rich.
That the rich metall lurked priuily,
In the rich metall, as they liuing were:
The goodly ordinance of this rich place,
So rich purueyance, ne them keepe with carefulnesse.
She saw so rich and royally arayd,
Which that rich Romane of white marble wrought,
For that rich girdle of faire Florimell,
Amongst the rest a iewell rich he found,
The goodly workes, and stones of rich assay,
The rich Cteatus, and Eurytus long;
Rich Oranochy, though but knowen late;
Can from all men so rich a kingdome hold;
By sweet Clonmell, adornes rich Waterford;
Ouer his Bridge, albee he rich or poore,
But he him selfe vppon th rich doth tyrannize.
Thereto she is full faire, and rich attired,
And all the wealth of rich men to the poore will draw.
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
They gan themselues addresse, full rich aguiz'd,
Where was a rich Pauilion ready pight,
They wore rich Mitres shaped like the Moone,
And on those Priests bestowed rich reward:
Presenting him with all the rich array,
and see her rich array.
Not of rich tissew, nor of cloth of gold,
Thus did she sit in royall rich estate,
Robbed her people, that full rich had beene,
Of costly Iuory, full rich beseene,
And afterwards of all her rich array;
That so rich frute should be from vs bereft;
That maketh wretch or happie, rich or poore:
But in that litle is both rich and wise.
Of his rich mould, did thrust it farre away,
Yet like a Diamond of rich regard,
His heart too high through his great riches store;
Riches, renowme, and principality,
Those be the riches fit for an aduent'rous knight.
All otherwise (said he) I riches read,
And to be Lord of those, that riches haue,
The massy roofe, and riches huge sustayne,
By riches and vnrighteous reward,
The royall riches and exceeding cost,
To doen his Nephew in all riches flow;
Exceeding riches and all pretious things,
Whereby great riches gathered manie a day,
Them seemd, that could so goodly riches gaine,
Whose smallest minute lost, no riches render may.
And causde great sackes with endlesse riches fraught,
And wondrous riches by his innouation.
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
Which doe all worldly riches farre excell,
His meanesse much, & make her th'others riches scorne.
And store of cares doth follow riches store.
For wisedome is most riches; fooles therefore
For his great riches and his greater might.
Such endlesse richesse, and so sumptuous shew;
To fill his bags, and richesse to compare;
